bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, January 5, 1953

div1.p: Hench requests that Nogueira send him information regarding the Camp Lazear dedication. He wonders if Kean could receive the Finlay decoration posthumously. He also discusses a posthumous decoration for Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, January 5, 1953
div1.opener:
January 5, 1953
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
Please see the enclosed letters, particularly that to Doctor Recio and that
to Senoritas Rojas and Cabrera.

I have been asked to make a formal presentation to the staff of the Mayo
Clinic describing the dedication of Camp Lazear. I am very anxious to receive
from you the sheet of paper on which I wrote the final arrangement for the
names of those who placed the wreaths. I have no corrected copy giving me
the order in which the wreaths were placed and the names of those who placed
them. I am most anxious to have this and hope that you did not discard this
paper. The newspapers do not give the correct arrangement of the names.
Could you also tell me in what order the medallions were unveiled? I failed
to make a note of this. I do know who unveiled them.

I am of course most anxious to have the films and to make some prints to be
sent to the many interested Americans, especially the yellow fever personalities.
Can you tell me when they might reach me? It is my understanding that you were
having prints made for all of those in Havana who were interested, including
Mr. Caswell, Doctor de Castro, Mrs. Moran, Senora Rojas, Estella Agramonte and
so on and that I was to have prints made for the yellow fever personalities
and the American Universities which sent wreaths.

I promised to send you, if at all possible, an actual copy of Doctor Agramonte's
article published in 1915 in the SCIENTIFIC MONTHLY. I find that I gave my
last extra copy to Senorita Cabrera. Perhaps she will lend it or give it to
you until such time as I can replace it by hunting for old copies in this
country; however this will not be an easy task.

I certainly enjoyed thoroughly my week with you in Cuba; it was a fine experience.
I would appreciate it greatly if you would send me the order in which the speeches
were given at the dedication and in due time of course I want a copy of your own
talk. Don't bother to translate it into English if this is too much of a job.
Juse send me a Spanish copy. Could you also send me the Havana addresses of
Mr. Frank Finlay and Senora Delgado or her son? Her son is mentioned in the
newspapers as Dr. Alberto Delgado. Is he a physician?

I have one slight regret. I wish somehow that General Kean could have received
posthumously the Finlay decoration. Perhaps it is not too late to consider this.
Do you think it could be done at the next meeting? He did so much for Reed. He
was Reed's right-hand man as you know and he also did a good deal for Cuba as you
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
- 2 -
January 5, 1953
well know, not only along the lines of sanitation for the Army but when for
months he was in charge, under General Wood, of all the civilian hospitals
and charitable institutions of Cuba. His services were such that years ago
the Cuban government hung his painting, which I think still hangs, in the
Sanitary Department.

I shall send Carroll's son some information regarding the dedication of Camp
Lazear. It is too bad he does not respond to you. If he shows any response,
perhaps later the Cuban government will see fit to give Carroll a posthumous
decoration. I would rather have it go posthumously to Carroll than to his son.

Summarizing my letter, I have made the following requests:
1. The order in which the wreaths were placed and those who placed them.
2. The order of the unveiling.
3. The films.
4. The address of Frank Finlay.
5. The address of Senora Delgado
6. The address of Dr. Alberto Delgado and is he a physician?
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
